author: Catie Low
title: Metcash announces new supermarkets boss
text:
Metcash chief executive, Ian Morrice, has revamped his executive team Dominic Lorrimer by Catie Low ï»¿ Struggling grocery wholesaler Metcash has installed one time Coles executive Steven Cain as chief executive of supermarkets and former Woolworths heavy hitter Mark Hewlett as executive general manager, new channels.
Mr Cain will drive Metcash's five year transformation program through its network of 1400 IGA outlets, as it battles fierce price competition from the supermarket majors as well as an increasingly emboldened discount sector.
Metcash is under pressure after unveiling a $640 million write-down last month that sent its shares tumbling.
During a three year stint at Coles, which ended a decade ago, Mr Cain was responsible for the group's grocery retail outlets, including convenience stores as well as it liquor and petrol operations.
More recently Mr Cain had held senior roles and advisory positions but his career history includes a stint at Asda where he played a significant part in the turn around of the group in the UK.
An engineer by training, Mr Cain said he was delighted to be joining Metcash at "an important time in the implementation of the Diamond Transformation Program."
The Diamond project is focused on refurbishing tired stores as well as revitalising its Black and Gold brand and the Price Match program.
There are signs already that the program is delivering some results at IGA stores .
 Price Match is a strategy where IGA matches the major supermarkets' shelf prices for a range of popular grocery items. The program was only officially rolled out in June.
In addition to his experience running the convenience business development for Woolworths and managing the day to day operation for Thomas Dux, Mr Hewlett brings considerable experience in the discount retail sector to Metcash's senior management.
Before joining Woolworths, Mr Hewlett spend more than a decade in the UK working with German discount giants Aldi and Lidl in senior retail, buying and format development roles.
Mr Hewlett said Metcash had "great distribution capacity on which to build new models."
